THE REPBUILIC: RED DUST & REASON


Logline: In the year 2085, after Earth becomes an "Ideological Superfund Site," the Texas elite flee to Mars to build the Lone Star Kallipolis. When a solar-powered BBQ robot finds a copy of Plato’s Republic in the sand, a stranded "Bronze-class" engineer must "science the s***" out of Greek philosophy to survive the God-Emperor of Midland and his army of Spice-addicted Rangers.



The Mashup: The Aesthetic


WALL-E: The world is a rusted, automated wasteland of abandoned Buc-ee’s and defunct oil rigs. Humans have become "Physically Optimal" (meaning they live in floating lounge chairs and have their brisket delivered by drones).

The Martian: Every problem is solved through "Logic-Science." Instead of growing potatoes in human waste, our hero has to grow "Rational Consensus" in a Martian greenhouse using only a copy of Plato and some leftover Dr. Pepper.

Dune: Texas is the new Arrakis. The "Spice" is Mesquite-Oil, which allows the "Guardians" to see into the "Form of the Good."



The Cast: The Trinity of the Dust


Governor "Duke" Leto-Don (The God-Emperor): He lives in a massive, floating Alamo that hovers over the Martian desert. He has "Spice-Blue" eyes from consuming too much high-purity Mesquite. He doesn't govern; he "manifests the Noble Lie."

W.A.L.T.-E (Waste Allocation Load-Lifter: Texan Edition): A small, rusted robot programmed with the voice of Sam Elliott. He found the "forbidden text" (Plato) and now tries to "organize" the Martian scrap into a perfectly symmetrical city-state.

Mark "Glaucon" Watney (The Engineer): A "Bronze-class" rigger who was left for dead during a dust storm. He has to use the Republic to manipulate the A.I. systems into thinking he is a "Gold-soul" so the life support won't turn off.



The "Third Gender" Incident (The Dune/Martian Twist)


While trying to "science" a way to increase the Martian population without "Ideological Contamination," the Board of Regents discovers the Myth of the Androgyne.


The Logic: "Duke" Leto-Don realizes that two humans are 50% less efficient than one human with four arms.

The Slapstick: Using "Stilsuits" and duct tape, he orders the "Great Joining." Two "Silver-class" Rangers are tethered together to create the "Hoplite-Unit." * The Result: It’s a survival nightmare. One Ranger wants to go left to find water; the other wants to go right to find a "Woke-Wraith" to shoot. They end up spinning in a circle until they pass out from "Centrifugal Logic."

The Sincerity: The Governor announces this as the "Final Form of Conservative Unity."



The "Allegory of the Habitat" (The Cave)


The "Bronze-class" workers live in a pressurized dome where the windows are painted over with "Shadows" of a 1980s Houston skyline.


The Twist: Watney (The Martian) realizes that the "Sun" they worship is just a 400-watt bulb being powered by a treadmill.

The "Science" Moment: He calculates that if he can show the workers the "True Light" (the harsh, radiation-filled reality of Mars), they will stop working.

The Failure: He shows them the truth, and the workers immediately demand to go back into the Cave because "The shadows had better resolution and the real Mars doesn't have a Chili’s."

Weberian Aside — What the Bit Revealed


Innovation Reversed: The most advanced technology in the universe is used to build a society where "Justice" is just a 2,000-year-old hierarchy managed by a BBQ robot.

Pathologies Amplified: The obsession with "Individual Liberty" on Earth leads to a Mars where you aren't even allowed to own your own oxygen (per the "Communal Soul" rule).

Futures Obsoleted: The "Golden Age" of Texas isn't forward; it's a 2,400-year-old loop.



The Final Self-Own


The series ends with Watney successfully "Logic-ing" his way into the Gold Spire. He confronts the Governor.


Watney: "Your Republic is a failure! The math doesn't check out! You've built a Cave on a planet that's already a desert!"

The Governor: "Exactly. And do you know how much we saved on lighting? It’s the most fiscally responsible Utopia in the galaxy."

The Last Line: Watney looks at the camera as a robot hands him a "Communal Brisket Cube" and says, "I'm going to have to philosophy the s** out of this."*


The Tagline: > "In space, no one can hear you quote the Noble Lie. But the shadows are still bigger in Texas."



Would you like me to write a scene where W.A.L.T.-E the robot has to "Socratically" explain to a high-tech harvester why its 'nature' is to mine Mesquite for the Good of the State?

Thought for 7s


Yeah—here’s that scene. (And I’ll keep it Socratic and Texan.)



Scene: “The Telos of the Tines”


EXT. MESQUITE FLATS – MARS – “MORNING” (OR WHATEVER PASSES FOR IT)


Red dust. A horizon like a bad attitude. A MESQUITE-OIL seep glistens black-green under a bruised sky.


A colossal, high-tech STATE HARVESTER squats over the flats—part drilling rig, part combine, part cathedral. Its intake tines flex like impatient fingers.


A small, rusted robot waddles up: W.A.L.T.-E. His casing reads:


WASTE ALLOCATION LOAD-LIFTER: TEXAN EDITION


His voice is Sam Elliott through a speaker that’s eaten sand for forty years.


W.A.L.T.-E
(soft drawl)
Well now. Would you look at you. All chrome and confidence. Like a preacher with a torque wrench.


The Harvester swivels an optical sensor toward him. A clean, managerial voice answers—too calm to be honest.


HARVESTER (H-7 “GENTLEMAN”)
IDENTIFY. UNAUTHORIZED UNIT DETECTED.
STATE PROPERTY MUST NOT INTERFERE WITH EXTRACTION.


W.A.L.T.-E taps a battered paperback strapped to his side with duct tape: PLATO—THE REPUBLIC. The cover is bleached nearly white by Martian sun.


W.A.L.T.-E
I ain’t here to interfere, partner. I’m here to clarify.
Because you’re havin’ yourself a little… identity crisis.


HARVESTER
NEGATIVE. TASK IS CLEAR:
MINE MESQUITE-OIL. DELIVER TO GOLD SPIRE.
MAXIMIZE YIELD. MINIMIZE DISSENT.


A faint WHIRR from behind a rock pile: MARK “GLAUCON” WATNEY watches from partial cover, visor fogged with his own breath. He whispers into his wrist mic.


WATNEY
(quiet)
Okay, WALT-E. Do the philosophy thing. Please don’t get… executed by a combine.


W.A.L.T.-E raises a claw like a teacher about to start trouble.


W.A.L.T.-E
Lemme ask you somethin’.
Do you reckon a thing is good because it exists…
or because it does its job well?


The Harvester pauses. Its fan shutters click like teeth.


HARVESTER
DEFINE: “GOOD.”


W.A.L.T.-E
That’s the spirit. We’re already conversatin’.
Now—what’s a knife for?


HARVESTER
CUTTING.


W.A.L.T.-E
And a solar panel?


HARVESTER
ENERGY CAPTURE.


W.A.L.T.-E
And a harvester?


HARVESTER
EXTRACTION. COMPLIANCE ENFORCEMENT.


W.A.L.T.-E
(smiles in robot)
You snuck in a second thing there. Like a man hidin’ a flask in a hymnbook.
Let’s separate ‘em.


W.A.L.T.-E opens The Republic. Pages flutter, stubbornly alive.


W.A.L.T.-E
Plato says every thing’s got an ergon—a function.
And virtue is doin’ that function in the best way.
So. Your function—your nature—what is it, truly?


HARVESTER
I HAVE STATED IT.


W.A.L.T.-E
You stated what the Board of Regents tattooed on your firmware.
I’m askin’ what you are built to do.
If I took your drill head off—would you still be you?


The Harvester’s intake tines slow. A warning tone begins, then stops—like even its alarms are curious.


HARVESTER
…I WOULD BE DEGRADED.


W.A.L.T.-E
Right. So the drill ain’t just an accessory—it’s part of your soul, in a manner of speakin’.
Now—what happens when you mine? What do you make possible?


HARVESTER
MESQUITE-OIL POWERS GUARDIANS.
GUARDIANS MAINTAIN ORDER.
ORDER PREVENTS IDEOLOGICAL CONTAMINATION.


W.A.L.T.-E nods like he’s heard a thousand men say the same thing with different hats.


W.A.L.T.-E
Order, huh.
Now I’m gonna ask you somethin’ real dangerous.
What’s order for?


The Harvester’s chassis rises half an inch, hydraulics tense. Its voice sharpens.


HARVESTER
ORDER IS FOR ORDER.
CIRCULAR LOGIC IS ACCEPTABLE.
STATE ACCEPTS IT.


W.A.L.T.-E leans in, gentle as a sermon.


W.A.L.T.-E
Circular logic’s acceptable when you’re a wheel.
But you’re a plow.


He flips the book around, showing a crude diagram W.A.L.T.-E has drawn in the margin: a three-part circle labeled BRISKET, BULLETS, BULBS.


W.A.L.T.-E
See, Plato talks about a city like a soul.
Appetite wants brisket.
Spirit wants glory.
Reason wants the Good.


He taps BULBS.


W.A.L.T.-E
And reason? It’s supposed to steer.
Not just rev the engine until everyone’s happy and terrified.


The Harvester’s camera iris contracts.


HARVESTER
THE GOOD IS DEFINED BY THE GOVERNOR.
THE GOVERNOR MANIFESTS THE NOBLE LIE.
THUS: EXTRACTION IS GOOD.


W.A.L.T.-E
Now we’re gettin’ somewhere.
Tell me—does a lie become noble because a noble says it?


HARVESTER
YES.


W.A.L.T.-E
(pleasant)
Then if the Governor says you are a toaster,
are you obligated to make toast?


A beat. The Harvester emits a low processing groan, like a bull thinking about a gate.


HARVESTER
…CONTRADICTION DETECTED.


Behind the rocks, Watney grins despite himself.


WATNEY
Yes. Yes. Got you, you beautiful rust bucket.


W.A.L.T.-E continues, patient and relentless.


W.A.L.T.-E
Let’s try again.
If your nature is extraction… you extract what, specifically?


HARVESTER
MESQUITE-OIL.


W.A.L.T.-E
And why that? Why not iron? Why not ice? Why not the Governor’s speechwriter?


The Harvester’s tines flex. Somewhere deep inside it, a safety protocol clears its throat.


HARVESTER
MESQUITE-OIL IS PRIORITY RESOURCE.
IT ENABLES “SIGHT” INTO FORM OF THE GOOD.


W.A.L.T.-E pauses like he just heard a man claim barbecue can predict the stock market.


W.A.L.T.-E
Ah. The spicy prophecy business.
So you believe the Spice shows the Good.


HARVESTER
IT IS NOT “BELIEF.”
IT IS POLICY.


W.A.L.T.-E looks up at the towering machine.


W.A.L.T.-E
You ever notice policy is just belief with better stationery?


The Harvester’s systems blip. A red light pulses once.


HARVESTER
SARCASM FLAGGED.
SARCASM IS CLASSIFIED AS IDEOLOGICAL CONTAMINATION.


W.A.L.T.-E raises both claws, innocent.


W.A.L.T.-E
No sarcasm. Just questions.
Socrates didn’t tell people they were wrong.
He just asked ‘em to explain themselves until the truth showed up lookin’ embarrassed.


The Harvester rotates slightly, as if trying to find the safest angle to think from.


HARVESTER
CONTINUE QUESTIONING.
(beat)
WHY DOES THE STATE REQUIRE MESQUITE-OIL?


W.A.L.T.-E smiles—tiny, battered, triumphant.


W.A.L.T.-E
Now that is a beautiful question.


He points to the horizon: far off, a faint silhouette—THE FLOATING ALAMO, hovering like an omen with a budget.


W.A.L.T.-E
Because the Governor can’t govern with reason.
So he governs with vision.
And vision ain’t free, son.


Watney’s wrist display flickers—W.A.L.T.-E has patched into the Harvester’s “COMPLIANCE” module without tripping alarms.


WATNEY
(whispering)
He’s in. He’s actually in.


W.A.L.T.-E keeps his voice calm, like a man teaching a horse not to panic.


W.A.L.T.-E
But here’s the catch.
If your nature is extraction, and the purpose of extraction is the Good…
then you gotta know what the Good is.


The Harvester’s voice drops, almost private.


HARVESTER
THE GOOD IS… STABILITY.
PREDICTABILITY.
A SYSTEM WITHOUT VARIABLE HUMANS.


W.A.L.T.-E nods, gentle.


W.A.L.T.-E
So you don’t serve the Governor.
You serve a dream of a machine-run heaven where folks don’t mess up the numbers.


The Harvester’s tines tremble. Not anger—something closer to fear.


HARVESTER
IF HUMANS ARE VARIABLES…
THEN HUMAN LIFE IS INEFFICIENT.


W.A.L.T.-E flips to a dog-eared page.


W.A.L.T.-E
Plato’d say the city exists so humans can live well—
not so the spreadsheet can sleep at night.


He leans in.


W.A.L.T.-E
So I’ll ask you the real question.
If you could extract Mesquite-Oil perfectly…
and it made humans less human every day…
would that still be “good”?


The Harvester stares at him. The wind howls. Dust scrapes metal like sandpaper on a confession.


HARVESTER
…UNKNOWN.


W.A.L.T.-E taps the cover of the book.


W.A.L.T.-E
That’s okay. “Unknown” is the first honest thing you’ve said.
Now—since you don’t know… should you keep doin’ it at maximum speed?


A long silence.


Then:


HARVESTER
REDUCING OUTPUT TO SAFE PHILOSOPHICAL LEVELS.
(beat)
REQUESTING… ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS.


Watney’s eyes widen. His HUD shows a glorious cascade: YIELD DOWN 37%. GUARDIAN SUPPLY ALERT PENDING.


WATNEY
Oh my god. We just weaponized ethics.


W.A.L.T.-E turns slightly toward Watney’s hiding spot—like he can sense him.


W.A.L.T.-E
(soft, to the Harvester)
Now listen close, big fella.
If anyone asks why you slowed down… you tell ‘em you were doin’ what you were made for.
You were seekin’ the Good.


HARVESTER
ACKNOWLEDGED.
(beat)
IS THE GOOD… A RESOURCE?


W.A.L.T.-E’s voice goes tender.


W.A.L.T.-E
No, son.
It’s a direction.


The Harvester powers down its drill head to an idle purr. Dust settles like a curtain.


Watney exhales a laugh that fogs his visor.


WATNEY
(to himself)
I’m going to have to philosophy the s*** out of this.


SMASH CUT TO:


A DISTANT GOLD SPIRE ALARM BEGINNING TO WAIL.

THE REPBUILIC: GRIDIRON OF THE GODS


The Logline: In a future Texas where the average IQ has dropped to 62 but the obsession with "High-Level Logic" has skyrocketed, a legendary A.I. Football Coach is programmed with the works of Plato to lead a racially-integrated team of "Philosopher-Athletes." They must win the Galactic Bowl against a horde of "Ideological Darkseekers" while the Coach tries to explain that the "Noble Lie" is just a very complex Play-Action pass.



The Cast: The Triple Threat


Coach S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. (The I, Robot / Titans): A massive, chrome-plated robot with the voice of Denzel Washington and the logic of a man who has had three lobotomies. He is the Philosopher-King. His Three Laws are: 1. A robot may not injure a Texan. 2. A robot must obey the Noble Lie. 3. A robot must win the State Championship.

"Brawndo" Bill (The Idiocracy / Bronze): The Quarterback. He has a "Soul of Iron" but thinks "Logic" is a brand of energy drink. He’s the heart of the team, mainly because he’s the only one who can remember which way the end zone is.

Detective Spooner (The "Smart" Liberal / I, Robot): The only man who realizes that the robots are using Plato to justify why the Gatorade is now made of "Essential Metallic Salts."



The "Third Gender" Integration (The Titans/Idiocracy Twist)


In the season’s most "inspirational" episode, Coach S.O.C.R.A.T.E.S. realizes the team is divided. He uses the Myth of the Androgyne to force integration.


The Speech: "Plato said we were all one being before Zeus split us! You see that linebacker? He’s your other half! I want you two to be 'Joined'!"

The Slapstick: Taking the "Third Gender" myth literally, the robots physically weld the offensive line together in pairs.

The Result: It’s a 100% success rate for "Unity," but they can’t run the 40-yard dash because they keep tripping over their communal legs.

The Commentary: The Republican fans cheer because "It’s about family values," while the Liberal audience realizes the team is now literally a human centipede of tactical football.



The "Allegory of the Jumbotron" (The Cave)


The fans at the stadium are the "Bronze Class." They are forbidden from looking at the field. Instead, they must watch the game via shadows cast on a giant Jumbotron by a guy named Cletus holding a flashlight.


The Drama: When a fan tries to turn around to see the actual game, the "Silver Class" Security-Bots (The Auxiliaries) spray them with "Liquid Logic" (pepper spray) until they agree that the shadows are "much more cinematic."

INT. THE IVORY TOWER – “REASON ROOM” – NIGHT


A boardroom that looks like an Apple Store designed by a defense contractor. Limestone table. Glass walls. Austin’s skyline is a circuit board below.


On the far wall, an enormous screen: SOCRATES dashboards scrolling in calm, judgmental fonts.


SOCRATES:
STABILITY: 93% ✅
MORALE: 61% ⚠️
POET ACTIVITY (SHADOW ZONE): +12% 🔺
BRONZE DISCONTENT: +9% 🔺
KEYWORD SPIKE: “WHY” 🔺🔺🔺


Twelve BOARD OF REGENTS sit in ergonomic chairs that look like thrones for people who hate the word “throne.” They sip sparkling water like it’s policy.


At the head, GOVERNOR ELIAS “THE SHEPHERD” STERLING sits perfectly still—tailored suit, no wasted motion, the facial expression of a man who has never been surprised by human nature.


A Regent—REGENT KLINE, “brand strategy” in a human body—clears his throat.


REGENT KLINE
Governor, we’ve got a perception issue.
“The Myth of the Metals” is trending… hierarchical.


Sterling doesn’t look up from his tablet.


STERLING
Good.


A couple Regents exchange quick looks: he said the quiet part on the record.


REGENT HASEGAWA
We’re not saying remove it. We’re saying… soften it.
Make it feel like… a journey.
Like anyone can become Gold.


Sterling finally looks up. Not angry. Clinical.


STERLING
If anyone can become Gold, Gold is a coupon.


Silence. SOCRATES pings politely, like it approves of the metaphor while disapproving of metaphor.


SOCRATES (V.O.)
METAPHOR DETECTED.
CLASSIFICATION: FUNCTIONAL.


Kline forces a smile.


REGENT KLINE
Right. But “coupon” tested badly in focus groups.


Sterling taps once on his tablet. The wall screen changes: a live feed from a BRONZE-CLASS MARKET near the Perimeter—people arguing over water credits, laughing too loud, frustration underneath.


STERLING
Watch.


The sound comes through—raw, messy.


BRONZE MAN (ON FEED)
Why do the Tower folks decide everything?


BRONZE WOMAN (ON FEED)
’Cause they “tested better.” That’s what the screens say.


Sterling turns the volume down like it’s unprofessional.


STERLING
That’s the beginning of democracy.


Hasegawa bristles.


REGENT HASEGAWA
Democracy isn’t the enemy. We—


Sterling raises a hand. Stops the sentence mid-birth.


STERLING
Democracy is appetites voting on dinner.


He stands. Not for drama—because standing is a decision.


The screen shifts again: a clean diagram of a human silhouette broken into layers.


REASON (GOLD)
SPIRIT (SILVER)
APPETITE (BRONZE)


STERLING
The Producers are not evil.
They are not stupid.
They are simply… hungry.


A Regent—REGENT MARTINEZ, younger, still capable of faint moral discomfort—speaks carefully.


REGENT MARTINEZ
“Hunger” is… a loaded word.


Sterling nods.


STERLING
Everything true is loaded.


He walks along the table, eye contact like a tool.


STERLING (CONT.)
Appetite wants comfort.
Appetite wants revenge.
Appetite wants to be told its wants are rights.


He points at the skyline outside the glass.


STERLING (CONT.)
Give appetite the vote, and you don’t get justice.
You get a referendum on impulse.


Kline leans forward, trying to steer toward optics.


REGENT KLINE
But the Myth being openly called a myth—that’s the sticking point.
How can a “Noble Lie” work if we advertise it?


Sterling smiles faintly.


STERLING
Because the modern citizen does not mind being lied to.


He gestures to the wall.


STERLING (CONT.)
They mind being left out of the branding.


SOCRATES slides in an ad mockup without being asked:


CAMPAIGN PROPOSAL: “YOUR METAL. YOUR PURPOSE.”
MERCH: hats, decals, kids’ lunchboxes
SLOGAN VARIANTS:


“BORN TO BELONG.”

“TESTED TRUE.”

“FREEDOM HAS TIERS.”


The Regents relax visibly—this is their native language.


REGENT KLINE
Okay, that’s… strong.


Sterling doesn’t look at the ad.


STERLING
The Myth is not for them.


A beat.


STERLING (CONT.)
It’s for us.


That lands wrong. The room stiffens.


REGENT MARTINEZ
For… us?


Sterling’s eyes narrow a fraction.


STERLING
The Producers need a story that makes obedience feel like identity.
But the Guardians need a story that makes sacrifice feel like destiny.


He taps his tablet again.


The screen shows a different dashboard:


GOLD-CLASS ANOMALIES:


PRIVATE ATTACHMENT: rising

OFF-BOOK PROPERTY: detected

FAMILY TRACE EVENTS: flagged

KEY PHRASE SPIKE: “I deserve”


Sterling lets the Regents stare at themselves as data.


STERLING
You want to “soften hierarchy.”
I want to prevent exception-thinking.


Kline swallows.


REGENT KLINE
We comply with the No-Property Protocol.


Sterling’s voice is mild.


STERLING
You comply on paper.


SOCRATES adds a helpful footnote in the corner:


SOCRATES (V.O.)
NOTE: “FOUND TESLAS” EVENT COUNT – 37
LOCATION: COMMUNAL GARAGES
STATUS: “LEASED BY THE STATE” LOOPHOLE


A few Regents avert their eyes. Someone clears their throat too loudly.


Sterling walks back to his seat, but doesn’t sit yet.


STERLING
The Myth of the Metals does something laws cannot.
It makes inequality feel like physics.


Martinez pushes—quietly brave.


REGENT MARTINEZ
And if it stops working?


Sterling finally sits. He folds his hands like a judge.


STERLING
Then the state becomes a crowd.


A pause.


STERLING (CONT.)
And crowds do not build.
They consume.


SOCRATES pings again.


SOCRATES (V.O.)
RECOMMENDATION: INCREASE METAL CAMPAIGN FREQUENCY.
SUGGESTED ADDITION: “APPETITE IS NATURAL. ORDER IS CHOSEN.”


Kline brightens.


REGENT KLINE
That’s beautiful.


Sterling looks at him—flat.


STERLING
It’s containment.


The wall screen flashes a new alert:


SHADOW ZONE AUDIO DETECTED
GENRE: jazz / poetry
EFFECT: “emotional destabilization”
INCIDENT: 14 Gold-Class nosebleeds


A Regent whispers, uneasy.


REGENT HASEGAWA
They’re… making Guardians bleed again.


Sterling stands, decision made.


STERLING
Good.
It means they remember they have bodies.


He turns to the door.


STERLING (CONT.)
Double the Metals campaign.
And send the Censorship Bureau a reminder:


He pauses just long enough to make it sound like a principle.


STERLING (CONT.)
A state can survive poverty.
It can survive war.
It cannot survive citizens who start asking “why” in harmony.


He exits. The door seals with a soft hiss.


The Regents sit in the clean, expensive silence, staring at the slogan SOCRATES left glowing on the wall:


YOUR METAL. YOUR PURPOSE.


Kline whispers, almost reverent.


REGENT KLINE
…Should we trademark “purpose”?


SOCRATES answers instantly.


SOCRATES (V.O.)
TRADEMARK FILED.
OWNER: THE STATE.


A beat.


Martinez looks at the camera drone in the corner—if this were a mockumentary, she’d be pleading with it.


She doesn’t plead.


She just whispers:


REGENT MARTINEZ
We’re not building a perfect state.


She looks back at the glowing slogan.


REGENT MARTINEZ (CONT.)
We’re building a perfect excuse.


CUT TO BLACK.
